posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
We successfully stumped the FTA and CSAs at Central Valley Regional this weekend, and won the prize of our autonomous skipping past steps in our Playoffs matches [and completely failing as a result] until we swapped the entire driver station computer for a spare that 581 had available. Thank you Dawgs!

TL;DR our no-name-brand USB-Ethernet adapter was slow to connect to FMS all weekend, and that component being bugged is the best root cause we have so far for three sequences where the Autonomous command appears to have skipped past certain steps.

Using our original driver station and a $15 “Amazon’s Finest” (it doesn’t have a brand marking) USB to Ethernet Adapter, we experience a very slow connection process to the FMS . Through Qualifications our well-tested autos ran fine, once we finally got connected.

The fun started in Match 3. OK, let’s revert code. Nope, same thing Match 8.

When we then tested the Autonomous sequence on the practice field with a direct Ethernet link from the radio to the DS, the computer again took a very long time to connect, but then successfully played the sequence in the correct order. So, we figured it was fixed (or at least we couldn’t replicate the failure) and sent it back out. Still got nothing! This is when we escalated to event volunteers for help.

Per CSAs & FTA at the event, there’s nothing in the Logs to indicate that there was an actual disconnection event that would cause the robot to skip steps on its own. No Field Fault. I’m away from the lab today, but happy to get them posted if folks are interested in poring over them.

The replacement DS that 581 lent us had a built-in Ethernet port, and connected to the FMS almost immediately. The Autonomous program ran correctly in Match 13, and we finally got to see that our shot setpoint actually did need adjustment to get to “flawless”… just in time to get eliminated and finish in 3rd.

It’s really hard to test for this in the lab, because we generally run on the high quality built-in wifi network drivers when we’re doing test sequences at home. Even tethered, the program did fine on the bad adapter. It wasn’t until FMS was in the loop that we got the truly bizarre autonomous behaviors.

We’re working on getting a Driver Station with built-in Ethernet port (presuming that the laptop hardware drivers for that built-in port will not suck) and also are trying TP-Link USB3-Ethernet adapters. Our experience on our Programmer’s Mac is that a TP-Link connects almost immediately, just like 581’s laptop did, which makes us believe ( “trust!” , the zoomerism of the day) that we should be able to use a name-brand adapter [TP-Link] at EBR even if we don’t replace the driver station laptop in time.

In the meantime, I’m kicking myself for accepting slow ds connection times, not spending $25 on TP-Link originally, and presumably never having to find this out the “fun” way. So, learn from my mistakes, get good ethernet driver components.

If you can afford it I highly recommend a Framework laptop. If anything gets damaged you have the ability to replace ports!!! Our lead programmer has one and I’m waiting for an excuse to spend money on a new laptop for myself!

Unsure of why there’s a thumbs down but here’s a link.

Framework Laptop: A thin, light, high-performance notebook that's upgradeable, repairable, and 100% yours. Order today with the latest configuration options.

posts.name: Weston Bosworth
posts.cooked: +1 for framework, at ORWIL I saw 2811 using one for their driverstation, and as someone whos had one for a while, it hasnt let me down yet

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
Use a name brand Ethernet adapter if you’re going USB dongle… or just buy a business class laptop. Dell has so many options with built in Ethernet cards still. I have a gaming Dell laptop with a GPU we use for programming that I got for like $600 this past year.

also… framework IO are just slotted in USB C modules… I mean that’s cool, but not worth the price they charge in my opinion.

posts.name: Nyx
posts.cooked: The flexibility and sheer number of ports is 100% worth it. Framework is a bit pricey though.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Everything and nothing, all at the same time

posts.custom_user_title: Everything and nothing, all at the same time

posts.name: Nick Foote
posts.cooked:
Also PSA: always plug in your driver station laptop to power. 3255 had massive input delay on their controller (5 seconds+) because they didn’t plug in the power, and the computer went into a power saving mode that put the USB ports into power saving mode. (Just to be clear, no blame 3255, expecting a laptop to function as a portable computer with a battery, is an entirely reasonable expectation.)

We built a pretty solid robot this year, to the point where the part of the system I trust the least, is the driver station laptop and the usb and network ports that have been abused.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Nick Foote - 2102 Team Paradox - Engineering Mentor and Founding Student

posts.custom_user_title: Nick Foote - 2102 Team Paradox - Engineering Mentor and Founding Student

posts.name: Nyx
posts.cooked: Also, update Windows. I recall a team who delayed a match because Windows decided to update quite literally the minute they set the computer down while prepping the match.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
All these tips and more are listed at Driver Station Best Practices — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

And if you have a tip that isn’t listed, you can make a PR

link_counts.title: Driver Station Best Practices — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked:
Related to this, some laptops will put ethernet or usb ports in that power savings mode, even when plugged in. So in addition to plugging in the laptop and setting power savings to the highest performance mode, it’s also a good idea to disable power management on all the ports.

(You can check by going into control panel, device manager, the right click “properties” of the thing you want to check. If there’s a Power Management tab, make sure “Allow the computer to turn off this device to save power” is NOT checked!!!)

s-neff:

TL;DR our no-name-brand USB-Ethernet adapter was slow to connect to FMS all weekend, and that component being bugged is the best root cause we have so far for three sequences where the Autonomous command appears to have skipped past certain steps.

Do you have a match or video of this? We’re seeing similar things but not sure if it actually is related at all.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked: CVR Semifinals 3, 8, 11… Compare to sequence in semis 13.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
I think what’s missing there is “expect your laptop to connect quickly (normal time period), if it does not you may have a bad xyz”

Wi-Fi is so dodgy to connect to that students get used to that experience and do not flag to me that a hard line ethernet is taking as long to negotiate as a wireless one…

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: The other thing is that depending on how the field reset is going, there’s not necessarily a good indication of the earliest time you should expect to get comms.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
The fact that it took over a literal minute to negotiate in the pit with an Ethernet in the radio port 2 on the practice field could have tipped me off to swapping the ethernet adapter on the DS side?

We had a Roborio1 on the bot for our first comp whose ethernet was so bugged that this feels fine in comparison. Prior to SFR Match 13 we spent 15min trying to get it to talk to different computers and no dice. So, “only” a literal minute to us compared to other things from this year.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: Once the robot’s back together I’ll measure how long it takes our driver station to connect to a fully booted robot over Ethernet.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
s-neff:

Our experience on our Programmer’s Mac is that a TP-Link connects almost immediately, just like 581’s laptop did

To be clear, you’re talking about the time it takes the driver station to connect with the driver station open when you plug an ethernet cord into an already booted RIO, correct?

We’re a bit confused on how an unreliable network connection could lead to skipped steps in auto but nothing observable in teleop and no disconnects or packet loss in the robot side logs. Doesn’t all the computing happen on the roborio? Are ethernet packet receives just blocking for a long time, causing issues?

posts.name: MikLast
posts.cooked:
Another +1 for the Framework. I saw at least 2 teams at Sammamish last weekend using them, more than a few teams have talked in the Framework discord about their success with them,  and I have one of my own since 2022. They even have a “factory seconds” section that are marked down for “excess parts” or small cosmetic issues.

If these are truly too expensive, a used thinkpad is also a great goto.

link_counts.title: Framework | Factory Seconds Framework Laptop 13 DIY Edition (11th Gen

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
Max_Morehead:

We’re a bit confused on how an unreliable network connection could lead to skipped steps in auto

I agree, it’s the weirdest set of failures I’ve ever seen. We won “stump the CSAs and FTA ”. The driver station swap was a complete “Hail Mary” change and I’m still surprised it worked. I will update this thread if we can isolate it to either the adapter or the PC.

As far as I understand Pathplanner/Autobuilder, the only dependency to the driver station should be selecting the auto to build. I’m not aware of runtime dependencies. That’s why I’m confused and posting what I think I know out to the community.

posts.name: Drew Williams
posts.cooked:
We ran into an issue at our first comp this year where we couldn’t connect to the FMS after doing multiple matches where using our USB ethernet adapter was fine.

Turns out we didn’t disable the built in ethernet port adapter on our laptop so the FMS was trying to connect over that instead of the USB one.

We just ended up switching to the built in laptop ethernet port as it has been fine for a couple years.  Just something to check for if you are having issues

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: I moved to California just for districts

posts.custom_user_title: I moved to California just for districts

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
s-neff:

Pathplanner/Autobuilder, the only dependency to the driver station

Maybe not the DS, I don’t know, but there is a dependency in the FMS . There is a dependency on flipping the PP path or not based on Alliance Color. We discovered that it is random when that data is available to the robot in a match and not guaranteed until autoInit . We build our paths and everything else in disabled before the match starts to save a lot of time and Alliance Color isn’t always available not matter how long you wait for it from the beginning of robotInit . That’s why the PP examples use a boolean supplier for the Alliance Color to be retrieved at “runtime” and not instantiation time.
